Confluence: Confluence of untyped lambda calculus üöß

Prev • Source • Next 

module plfa.part2.Confluence where

Introduction

In this chapter we prove that beta reduction is confluent, a property also known as Church-Rosser. That is, if there are reduction sequences from any term L to two different terms M‚ÇÅ and M‚ÇÇ, then there exist reduction sequences from those two terms to some common term N. In pictures:

    L
   / \
  /   \
 /     \
M‚ÇÅ      M‚ÇÇ
 \     /
  \   /
   \ /
    N

where downward lines are instances of ‚Äî‚Ü†.

Confluence is studied in many other kinds of rewrite systems besides the lambda calculus, and it is well known how to prove confluence in rewrite systems that enjoy the diamond property, a single-step version of confluence. Let ‚áõ be a relation. Then ‚áõ has the diamond property if whenever L ‚áõ M‚ÇÅ and L ‚áõ M‚ÇÇ, then there exists an N such that M‚ÇÅ ‚áõ N and M‚ÇÇ ‚áõ N. This is just an instance of the same picture above, where downward lines are now instance of ‚áõ. If we write ‚áõ* for the reflexive and transitive closure of ‚áõ, then confluence of ‚áõ* follows immediately from the diamond property.

Unfortunately, reduction in the lambda calculus does not satisfy the diamond property. Here is a counter example.

(Œª x. x x)((Œª x. x) a) ‚Äî‚Üí (Œª x. x x) a
(Œª x. x x)((Œª x. x) a) ‚Äî‚Üí ((Œª x. x) a) ((Œª x. x) a)

Both terms can reduce to a a, but the second term requires two steps to get there, not one.

To side-step this problem, we‚Äôll define an auxilliary reduction relation, called parallel reduction, that can perform many reductions simultaneously and thereby satisfy the diamond property. Furthermore, we show that a parallel reduction sequence exists between any two terms if and only if a beta reduction sequence exists between them. Thus, we can reduce the proof of confluence for beta reduction to confluence for parallel reduction.

Imports

open import Relation.Binary.PropositionalEquality using (_‚â°_; refl)
open import Function using (_‚àò_)
open import Data.Product using (_√ó_; Œ£; Œ£-syntax; ‚àÉ; ‚àÉ-syntax; proj‚ÇÅ; proj‚ÇÇ)
  renaming (_,_ to ‚ü®_,_‚ü©)
open import plfa.part2.Substitution using (Rename; Subst)
open import plfa.part2.Untyped
  using (_‚Äî‚Üí_; Œ≤; Œæ‚ÇÅ; Œæ‚ÇÇ; Œ∂; _‚Äî‚Ü†_; begin_; _‚Äî‚Üí‚ü®_‚ü©_; _‚Äî‚Ü†‚ü®_‚ü©_; _‚àé;
  abs-cong; appL-cong; appR-cong; ‚Äî‚Ü†-trans;
  _‚ä¢_; _‚àã_; `_; #_; _,_; ‚òÖ; ∆õ_; _¬∑_; _[_];
  rename; ext; exts; Z; S_; subst; subst-zero)

Parallel Reduction

The parallel reduction relation is defined as follows.

infix 2 _‚áõ_

data _‚áõ_ : ‚àÄ {Œì A} ‚Üí (Œì ‚ä¢ A) ‚Üí (Œì ‚ä¢ A) ‚Üí Set where

  pvar : ‚àÄ{Œì A}{x : Œì ‚àã A}
      ---------
    ‚Üí (` x) ‚áõ (` x)

  pabs : ‚àÄ{Œì}{N N‚Ä≤ : Œì , ‚òÖ ‚ä¢ ‚òÖ}
    ‚Üí N ‚áõ N‚Ä≤
      ----------
    ‚Üí ∆õ N ‚áõ ∆õ N‚Ä≤

  papp : ‚àÄ{Œì}{L L‚Ä≤ M M‚Ä≤ : Œì ‚ä¢ ‚òÖ}
    ‚Üí L ‚áõ L‚Ä≤
    ‚Üí M ‚áõ M‚Ä≤
      -----------------
    ‚Üí L ¬∑ M ‚áõ L‚Ä≤ ¬∑ M‚Ä≤

  pbeta : ‚àÄ{Œì}{N N‚Ä≤  : Œì , ‚òÖ ‚ä¢ ‚òÖ}{M M‚Ä≤ : Œì ‚ä¢ ‚òÖ}
    ‚Üí N ‚áõ N‚Ä≤
    ‚Üí M ‚áõ M‚Ä≤
      -----------------------
    ‚Üí (∆õ N) ¬∑ M  ‚áõ  N‚Ä≤ [ M‚Ä≤ ]

The first three rules are congruences that reduce each of their parts simultaneously. The last rule reduces a lambda term and term in parallel followed by a beta step.

We remark that the pabs, papp, and pbeta rules perform reduction on all their subexpressions simultaneously. Also, the pabs rule is akin to the Œ∂ rule and pbeta is akin to Œ≤.

Parallel reduction is reflexive.

par-refl : ‚àÄ{Œì A}{M : Œì ‚ä¢ A} ‚Üí M ‚áõ M
par-refl {Œì} {A} {` x} = pvar
par-refl {Œì} {‚òÖ} {∆õ N} = pabs par-refl
par-refl {Œì} {‚òÖ} {L ¬∑ M} = papp par-refl par-refl

We define the sequences of parallel reduction as follows.

infix  2 _‚áõ*_
infixr 2 _‚áõ‚ü®_‚ü©_
infix  3 _‚àé

data _‚áõ*_ : ‚àÄ {Œì A} ‚Üí (Œì ‚ä¢ A) ‚Üí (Œì ‚ä¢ A) ‚Üí Set where

  _‚àé : ‚àÄ {Œì A} (M : Œì ‚ä¢ A)
      --------
    ‚Üí M ‚áõ* M

  _‚áõ‚ü®_‚ü©_ : ‚àÄ {Œì A} (L : Œì ‚ä¢ A) {M N : Œì ‚ä¢ A}
    ‚Üí L ‚áõ M
    ‚Üí M ‚áõ* N
      ---------
    ‚Üí L ‚áõ* N

Exercise par-diamond-eg (practice)

Revisit the counter example to the diamond property for reduction by showing that the diamond property holds for parallel reduction in that case.

-- Your code goes here

Equivalence between parallel reduction and reduction

Here we prove that for any M and N, M ‚áõ* N if and only if M ‚Äî‚Ü† N. The only-if direction is particularly easy. We start by showing that if M ‚Äî‚Üí N, then M ‚áõ N. The proof is by induction on the reduction M ‚Äî‚Üí N.

beta-par : ‚àÄ{Œì A}{M N : Œì ‚ä¢ A}
  ‚Üí M ‚Äî‚Üí N
    ------
  ‚Üí M ‚áõ N
beta-par {Œì} {‚òÖ} {L ¬∑ M} (Œæ‚ÇÅ r) = papp (beta-par {M = L} r) par-refl
beta-par {Œì} {‚òÖ} {L ¬∑ M} (Œæ‚ÇÇ r) = papp par-refl (beta-par {M = M} r)
beta-par {Œì} {‚òÖ} {(∆õ N) ¬∑ M} Œ≤ = pbeta par-refl par-refl
beta-par {Œì} {‚òÖ} {∆õ N} (Œ∂ r) = pabs (beta-par r)

With this lemma in hand we complete the only-if direction, that M ‚Äî‚Ü† N implies M ‚áõ* N. The proof is a straightforward induction on the reduction sequence M ‚Äî‚Ü† N.

betas-pars : ‚àÄ{Œì A} {M N : Œì ‚ä¢ A}
  ‚Üí M ‚Äî‚Ü† N
    ------
  ‚Üí M ‚áõ* N
betas-pars {Œì} {A} {M‚ÇÅ} {.M‚ÇÅ} (M‚ÇÅ ‚àé) = M‚ÇÅ ‚àé
betas-pars {Œì} {A} {.L} {N} (L ‚Äî‚Üí‚ü® b ‚ü© bs) =
   L ‚áõ‚ü® beta-par b ‚ü© betas-pars bs

Now for the other direction, that M ‚áõ* N implies M ‚Äî‚Ü† N. The proof of this direction is a bit different because it‚Äôs not the case that M ‚áõ N implies M ‚Äî‚Üí N. After all, M ‚áõ N performs many reductions. So instead we shall prove that M ‚áõ N implies M ‚Äî‚Ü† N.

par-betas : ‚àÄ{Œì A}{M N : Œì ‚ä¢ A}
  ‚Üí M ‚áõ N
    ------
  ‚Üí M ‚Äî‚Ü† N
par-betas {Œì} {A} {.(` _)} (pvar{x = x}) = (` x) ‚àé
par-betas {Œì} {‚òÖ} {∆õ N} (pabs p) = abs-cong (par-betas p)
par-betas {Œì} {‚òÖ} {L ¬∑ M} (papp {L = L}{L‚Ä≤}{M}{M‚Ä≤} p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ) =
    begin
    L ¬∑ M   ‚Äî‚Ü†‚ü® appL-cong{M = M} (par-betas p‚ÇÅ) ‚ü©
    L‚Ä≤ ¬∑ M  ‚Äî‚Ü†‚ü® appR-cong (par-betas p‚ÇÇ) ‚ü©
    L‚Ä≤ ¬∑ M‚Ä≤
    ‚àé
par-betas {Œì} {‚òÖ} {(∆õ N) ¬∑ M} (pbeta{N‚Ä≤ = N‚Ä≤}{M‚Ä≤ = M‚Ä≤} p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ) =
    begin
    (∆õ N) ¬∑ M                    ‚Äî‚Ü†‚ü® appL-cong{M = M} (abs-cong (par-betas p‚ÇÅ)) ‚ü©
    (∆õ N‚Ä≤) ¬∑ M                   ‚Äî‚Ü†‚ü® appR-cong{L = ∆õ N‚Ä≤} (par-betas p‚ÇÇ)  ‚ü©
    (∆õ N‚Ä≤) ¬∑ M‚Ä≤                  ‚Äî‚Üí‚ü® Œ≤ ‚ü©
     N‚Ä≤ [ M‚Ä≤ ]
    ‚àé

The proof is by induction on M ‚áõ N.

  • Suppose x ‚áõ x. We immediately have x ‚Äî‚Ü† x.

  • Suppose ∆õ N ‚áõ ∆õ N‚Ä≤ because N ‚áõ N‚Ä≤. By the induction hypothesis we have N ‚Äî‚Ü† N‚Ä≤. We conclude that ∆õ N ‚Äî‚Ü† ∆õ N‚Ä≤ because ‚Äî‚Ü† is a congruence.

  • Suppose L ¬∑ M ‚áõ L‚Ä≤ ¬∑ M‚Ä≤ because L ‚áõ L‚Ä≤ and M ‚áõ M‚Ä≤. By the induction hypothesis, we have L ‚Äî‚Ü† L‚Ä≤ and M ‚Äî‚Ü† M‚Ä≤. So L ¬∑ M ‚Äî‚Ü† L‚Ä≤ ¬∑ M and then L‚Ä≤ ¬∑ M ‚Äî‚Ü† L‚Ä≤ ¬∑ M‚Ä≤ because ‚Äî‚Ü† is a congruence.

  • Suppose (∆õ N) ¬∑ M ‚áõ N‚Ä≤ [ M‚Ä≤ ] because N ‚áõ N‚Ä≤ and M ‚áõ M‚Ä≤. By similar reasoning, we have (∆õ N) ¬∑ M ‚Äî‚Ü† (∆õ N‚Ä≤) ¬∑ M‚Ä≤ which we can following with the Œ≤ reduction (∆õ N‚Ä≤) ¬∑ M‚Ä≤ ‚Äî‚Üí N‚Ä≤ [ M‚Ä≤ ].

With this lemma in hand, we complete the proof that M ‚áõ* N implies M ‚Äî‚Ü† N with a simple induction on M ‚áõ* N.

pars-betas : ‚àÄ{Œì A} {M N : Œì ‚ä¢ A}
  ‚Üí M ‚áõ* N
    ------
  ‚Üí M ‚Äî‚Ü† N
pars-betas (M‚ÇÅ ‚àé) = M‚ÇÅ ‚àé
pars-betas (L ‚áõ‚ü® p ‚ü© ps) = ‚Äî‚Ü†-trans (par-betas p) (pars-betas ps)

Substitution lemma for parallel reduction

Our next goal is the prove the diamond property for parallel reduction. But to do that, we need to prove that substitution respects parallel reduction. That is, if N ‚áõ N‚Ä≤ and M ‚áõ M‚Ä≤, then N [ M ] ‚áõ N‚Ä≤ [ M‚Ä≤ ]. We cannot prove this directly by induction, so we generalize it to: if N ‚áõ N‚Ä≤ and the substitution œÉ pointwise parallel reduces to œÑ, then subst œÉ N ‚áõ subst œÑ N‚Ä≤. We define the notion of pointwise parallel reduction as follows.

par-subst : ‚àÄ{Œì Œî} ‚Üí Subst Œì Œî ‚Üí Subst Œì Œî ‚Üí Set
par-subst {Œì}{Œî} œÉ œÉ‚Ä≤ = ‚àÄ{A}{x : Œì ‚àã A} ‚Üí œÉ x ‚áõ œÉ‚Ä≤ x

Because substitution depends on the extension function exts, which in turn relies on rename, we start with a version of the substitution lemma, called par-rename, that is specialized to renamings. The proof of par-rename relies on the fact that renaming and substitution commute with one another, which is a lemma that we import from Chapter Substitution and restate here.

rename-subst-commute : ‚àÄ{Œì Œî}{N : Œì , ‚òÖ ‚ä¢ ‚òÖ}{M : Œì ‚ä¢ ‚òÖ}{œÅ : Rename Œì Œî }
    ‚Üí (rename (ext œÅ) N) [ rename œÅ M ] ‚â° rename œÅ (N [ M ])
rename-subst-commute {N = N} = plfa.part2.Substitution.rename-subst-commute {N = N}

Now for the par-rename lemma.

par-rename : ‚àÄ{Œì Œî A} {œÅ : Rename Œì Œî} {M M‚Ä≤ : Œì ‚ä¢ A}
  ‚Üí M ‚áõ M‚Ä≤
    ------------------------
  ‚Üí rename œÅ M ‚áõ rename œÅ M‚Ä≤
par-rename pvar = pvar
par-rename (pabs p) = pabs (par-rename p)
par-rename (papp p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ) = papp (par-rename p‚ÇÅ) (par-rename p‚ÇÇ)
par-rename {Œì}{Œî}{A}{œÅ} (pbeta{Œì}{N}{N‚Ä≤}{M}{M‚Ä≤} p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ)
    with pbeta (par-rename{œÅ = ext œÅ} p‚ÇÅ) (par-rename{œÅ = œÅ} p‚ÇÇ)
... | G rewrite rename-subst-commute{Œì}{Œî}{N‚Ä≤}{M‚Ä≤}{œÅ} = G

The proof is by induction on M ‚áõ M‚Ä≤. The first four cases are straightforward so we just consider the last one for pbeta.

  • Suppose (∆õ N) ¬∑ M ‚áõ N‚Ä≤ [ M‚Ä≤ ] because N ‚áõ N‚Ä≤ and M ‚áõ M‚Ä≤. By the induction hypothesis, we have rename (ext œÅ) N ‚áõ rename (ext œÅ) N‚Ä≤ and rename œÅ M ‚áõ rename œÅ M‚Ä≤. So by pbeta we have (∆õ rename (ext œÅ) N) ¬∑ (rename œÅ M) ‚áõ (rename (ext œÅ) N) [ rename œÅ M ]. However, to conclude we instead need parallel reduction to rename œÅ (N [ M ]). But thankfully, renaming and substitution commute with one another.

With the par-rename lemma in hand, it is straightforward to show that extending substitutions preserves the pointwise parallel reduction relation.

par-subst-exts : ‚àÄ{Œì Œî} {œÉ œÑ : Subst Œì Œî}
  ‚Üí par-subst œÉ œÑ
    ------------------------------------------
  ‚Üí ‚àÄ{B} ‚Üí par-subst (exts œÉ {B = B}) (exts œÑ)
par-subst-exts s {x = Z} = pvar
par-subst-exts s {x = S x} = par-rename s

The next lemma that we need for proving that substitution respects parallel reduction is the following which states that simultaneoous substitution commutes with single substitution. We import this lemma from Chapter Substitution and restate it below.

subst-commute : ‚àÄ{Œì Œî}{N : Œì , ‚òÖ ‚ä¢ ‚òÖ}{M : Œì ‚ä¢ ‚òÖ}{œÉ : Subst Œì Œî }
  ‚Üí subst (exts œÉ) N [ subst œÉ M ] ‚â° subst œÉ (N [ M ])
subst-commute {N = N} = plfa.part2.Substitution.subst-commute {N = N}

We are ready to prove that substitution respects parallel reduction.

subst-par : ‚àÄ{Œì Œî A} {œÉ œÑ : Subst Œì Œî} {M M‚Ä≤ : Œì ‚ä¢ A}
  ‚Üí par-subst œÉ œÑ  ‚Üí  M ‚áõ M‚Ä≤
    --------------------------
  ‚Üí subst œÉ M ‚áõ subst œÑ M‚Ä≤
subst-par {Œì} {Œî} {A} {œÉ} {œÑ} {` x} s pvar = s
subst-par {Œì} {Œî} {A} {œÉ} {œÑ} {∆õ N} s (pabs p) =
  pabs (subst-par {œÉ = exts œÉ} {œÑ = exts œÑ}
        (Œª {A}{x} ‚Üí par-subst-exts s {x = x}) p)
subst-par {Œì} {Œî} {‚òÖ} {œÉ} {œÑ} {L ¬∑ M} s (papp p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ) =
  papp (subst-par s p‚ÇÅ) (subst-par s p‚ÇÇ)
subst-par {Œì} {Œî} {‚òÖ} {œÉ} {œÑ} {(∆õ N) ¬∑ M} s (pbeta{N‚Ä≤ = N‚Ä≤}{M‚Ä≤ = M‚Ä≤} p‚ÇÅ p‚ÇÇ)
    with pbeta (subst-par{œÉ = exts œÉ}{œÑ = exts œÑ}{M = N}
                        (Œª{A}{x} ‚Üí par-subst-exts s {x = x}) p‚ÇÅ)
               (subst-par {œÉ = œÉ} s p‚ÇÇ)
... | G rewrite subst-commute{N = N‚Ä≤}{M = M‚Ä≤}{œÉ = œÑ} = G

We proceed by induction on M ‚áõ M‚Ä≤.

  • Suppose x ‚áõ x. We conclude that œÉ x ‚áõ œÑ x using the premise par-subst œÉ œÑ.

  • Suppose ∆õ N ‚áõ ∆õ N‚Ä≤ because N ‚áõ N‚Ä≤. To use the induction hypothesis, we need par-subst (exts œÉ) (exts œÑ), which we obtain by par-subst-exts. So we have subst (exts œÉ) N ‚áõ subst (exts œÑ) N‚Ä≤ and conclude by rule pabs.

  • Suppose L ¬∑ M ‚áõ L‚Ä≤ ¬∑ M‚Ä≤ because L ‚áõ L‚Ä≤ and M ‚áõ M‚Ä≤. By the induction hypothesis we have subst œÉ L ‚áõ subst œÑ L‚Ä≤ and subst œÉ M ‚áõ subst œÑ M‚Ä≤, so we conclude by rule papp.

  • Suppose (∆õ N) ¬∑ M ‚áõ N‚Ä≤ [ M‚Ä≤ ] because N ‚áõ N‚Ä≤ and M ‚áõ M‚Ä≤. Again we obtain par-subst (exts œÉ) (exts œÑ) by par-subst-exts. So by the induction hypothesis, we have subst (exts œÉ) N ‚áõ subst (exts œÑ) N‚Ä≤ and subst œÉ M ‚áõ subst œÑ M‚Ä≤. Then by rule pbeta, we have parallel reduction to subst (exts œÑ) N‚Ä≤ [ subst œÑ M‚Ä≤ ]. Substitution commutes with itself in the following sense. For any œÉ, N, and M, we have

      (subst (exts œÉ) N) [ subst œÉ M ] ‚â° subst œÉ (N [ M ])

    So we have parallel reduction to subst œÑ (N‚Ä≤ [ M‚Ä≤ ]).

Of course, if M ‚áõ M‚Ä≤, then subst-zero M pointwise parallel reduces to subst-zero M‚Ä≤.

par-subst-zero : ‚àÄ{Œì}{A}{M M‚Ä≤ : Œì ‚ä¢ A}
       ‚Üí M ‚áõ M‚Ä≤
       ‚Üí par-subst (subst-zero M) (subst-zero M‚Ä≤)
par-subst-zero {M} {M‚Ä≤} p {A} {Z} = p
par-subst-zero {M} {M‚Ä≤} p {A} {S x} = pvar

We conclude this section with the desired corollary, that substitution respects parallel reduction.

sub-par : ‚àÄ{Œì A B} {N N‚Ä≤ : Œì , A ‚ä¢ B} {M M‚Ä≤ : Œì ‚ä¢ A}
  ‚Üí N ‚áõ N‚Ä≤
  ‚Üí M ‚áõ M‚Ä≤
    --------------------------
  ‚Üí N [ M ] ‚áõ N‚Ä≤ [ M‚Ä≤ ]
sub-par pn pm = subst-par (par-subst-zero pm) pn

Parallel reduction satisfies the diamond property

The heart of the confluence proof is made of stone, or rather, of diamond! We show that parallel reduction satisfies the diamond property: that if M ‚áõ N and M ‚áõ N‚Ä≤, then N ‚áõ L and N‚Ä≤ ‚áõ L for some L. The typical proof is an induction on M ‚áõ N and M ‚áõ N‚Ä≤ so that every possible pair gives rise to a witeness L given by performing enough beta reductions in parallel.

However, a simpler approach is to perform as many beta reductions in parallel as possible on M, say M ‚Å∫, and then show that N also parallel reduces to M ‚Å∫. This is the idea of Takahashi‚Äôs complete development. The desired property may be illustrated as

    M
   /|
  / |
 /  |
N   2
 \  |
  \ |
   \|
    M‚Å∫

where downward lines are instances of ‚áõ, so we call it the triangle property.

_‚Å∫ : ‚àÄ {Œì A}
  ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ A ‚Üí Œì ‚ä¢ A
(` x) ‚Å∫       =  ` x
(∆õ M) ‚Å∫       = ∆õ (M ‚Å∫)
((∆õ N) ¬∑ M) ‚Å∫ = N ‚Å∫ [ M ‚Å∫ ]
(L ¬∑ M) ‚Å∫     = L ‚Å∫ ¬∑ (M ‚Å∫)

par-triangle : ‚àÄ {Œì A} {M N : Œì ‚ä¢ A}
  ‚Üí M ‚áõ N
    -------
  ‚Üí N ‚áõ M ‚Å∫
par-triangle pvar          = pvar
par-triangle (pabs p)      = pabs (par-triangle p)
par-triangle (pbeta p1 p2) = sub-par (par-triangle p1) (par-triangle p2)
par-triangle (papp {L = ∆õ _ } (pabs p1) p2) =
  pbeta (par-triangle p1) (par-triangle p2)
par-triangle (papp {L = ` _}   p1 p2) = papp (par-triangle p1) (par-triangle p2)
par-triangle (papp {L = _ ¬∑ _} p1 p2) = papp (par-triangle p1) (par-triangle p2)

The proof of the triangle property is an induction on M ‚áõ N.

  • Suppose x ‚áõ x. Clearly x ‚Å∫ = x, so x ‚áõ x.

  • Suppose ∆õ M ‚áõ ∆õ N. By the induction hypothesis we have N ‚áõ M ‚Å∫ and by definition (Œª M) ‚Å∫ = Œª (M ‚Å∫), so we conclude that Œª N ‚áõ Œª (M ‚Å∫).

  • Suppose (Œª N) ¬∑ M ‚áõ N‚Ä≤ [ M‚Ä≤ ]. By the induction hypothesis, we have N‚Ä≤ ‚áõ N ‚Å∫ and M‚Ä≤ ‚áõ M ‚Å∫. Since substitution respects parallel reduction, it follows that N‚Ä≤ [ M‚Ä≤ ] ‚áõ N ‚Å∫ [ M ‚Å∫ ], but the right hand side is exactly ((Œª N) ¬∑ M) ‚Å∫, hence N‚Ä≤ [ M‚Ä≤ ] ‚áõ ((Œª N) ¬∑ M) ‚Å∫.

  • Suppose (Œª L) ¬∑ M ‚áõ (Œª L‚Ä≤) ¬∑ M‚Ä≤. By the induction hypothesis we have L‚Ä≤ ‚áõ L ‚Å∫ and M‚Ä≤ ‚áõ M ‚Å∫; by definition ((Œª L) ¬∑ M) ‚Å∫ = L ‚Å∫ [ M ‚Å∫ ]. It follows (Œª L‚Ä≤) ¬∑ M‚Ä≤ ‚áõ L ‚Å∫ [ M ‚Å∫ ].

  • Suppose x ¬∑ M ‚áõ x ¬∑ M‚Ä≤. By the induction hypothesis we have M‚Ä≤ ‚áõ M ‚Å∫ and x ‚áõ x ‚Å∫ so that x ¬∑ M‚Ä≤ ‚áõ x ¬∑ M ‚Å∫. The remaining case is proved in the same way, so we ignore it. (As there is currently no way in Agda to expand the catch-all pattern in the definition of _‚Å∫ for us before checking the right-hand side, we have to write down the remaining case explicitly.)

The diamond property then follows by halving the diamond into two triangles.

    M
   /|\
  / | \
 /  |  \
N   2   N‚Ä≤
 \  |  /
  \ | /
   \|/
    M‚Å∫

That is, the diamond property is proved by applying the triangle property on each side with the same confluent term M ‚Å∫.

par-diamond : ‚àÄ{Œì A} {M N N‚Ä≤ : Œì ‚ä¢ A}
  ‚Üí M ‚áõ N
  ‚Üí M ‚áõ N‚Ä≤
    ---------------------------------
  ‚Üí Œ£[ L ‚àà Œì ‚ä¢ A ] (N ‚áõ L) √ó (N‚Ä≤ ‚áõ L)
par-diamond {M = M} p1 p2 = ‚ü® M ‚Å∫ , ‚ü® par-triangle p1 , par-triangle p2 ‚ü© ‚ü©

This step is optional, though, in the presence of triangle property.

Exercise (practice)

  • Prove the diamond property par-diamond directly by induction on M ‚áõ N and M ‚áõ N‚Ä≤.

  • Draw pictures that represent the proofs of each of the six cases in the direct proof of par-diamond. The pictures should consist of nodes and directed edges, where each node is labeled with a term and each edge represents parallel reduction.

Proof of confluence for parallel reduction

As promised at the beginning, the proof that parallel reduction is confluent is easy now that we know it satisfies the triangle property. We just need to prove the strip lemma, which states that if M ‚áõ N and M ‚áõ* N‚Ä≤, then N ‚áõ* L and N‚Ä≤ ‚áõ L for some L. The following diagram illustrates the strip lemma

    M
   / \
  1   *
 /     \
N       N‚Ä≤
 \     /
  *   1
   \ /
    L

where downward lines are instances of ‚áõ or ‚áõ*, depending on how they are marked.

The proof of the strip lemma is a straightforward induction on M ‚áõ* N‚Ä≤, using the triangle property in the induction step.

strip : ‚àÄ{Œì A} {M N N‚Ä≤ : Œì ‚ä¢ A}
  ‚Üí M ‚áõ N
  ‚Üí M ‚áõ* N‚Ä≤
    ------------------------------------
  ‚Üí Œ£[ L ‚àà Œì ‚ä¢ A ] (N ‚áõ* L)  √ó  (N‚Ä≤ ‚áõ L)
strip{Œì}{A}{M}{N}{N‚Ä≤} mn (M ‚àé) = ‚ü® N , ‚ü® N ‚àé , mn ‚ü© ‚ü©
strip{Œì}{A}{M}{N}{N‚Ä≤} mn (M ‚áõ‚ü® mm' ‚ü© m'n')
  with strip (par-triangle mm') m'n'
... | ‚ü® L , ‚ü® ll' , n'l' ‚ü© ‚ü© = ‚ü® L , ‚ü® N ‚áõ‚ü® par-triangle mn ‚ü© ll' , n'l' ‚ü© ‚ü©

The proof of confluence for parallel reduction is now proved by induction on the sequence M ‚áõ* N, using the above lemma in the induction step.

par-confluence : ‚àÄ{Œì A} {L M‚ÇÅ M‚ÇÇ : Œì ‚ä¢ A}
  ‚Üí L ‚áõ* M‚ÇÅ
  ‚Üí L ‚áõ* M‚ÇÇ
    ------------------------------------
  ‚Üí Œ£[ N ‚àà Œì ‚ä¢ A ] (M‚ÇÅ ‚áõ* N) √ó (M‚ÇÇ ‚áõ* N)
par-confluence {Œì}{A}{L}{.L}{N} (L ‚àé) L‚áõ*N = ‚ü® N , ‚ü® L‚áõ*N , N ‚àé ‚ü© ‚ü©
par-confluence {Œì}{A}{L}{M‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤}{M‚ÇÇ} (L ‚áõ‚ü® L‚áõM‚ÇÅ ‚ü© M‚ÇÅ‚áõ*M‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤) L‚áõ*M‚ÇÇ
    with strip L‚áõM‚ÇÅ L‚áõ*M‚ÇÇ
... | ‚ü® N , ‚ü® M‚ÇÅ‚áõ*N , M‚ÇÇ‚áõN ‚ü© ‚ü©
      with par-confluence M‚ÇÅ‚áõ*M‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤ M‚ÇÅ‚áõ*N
...   | ‚ü® N‚Ä≤ , ‚ü® M‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤‚áõ*N‚Ä≤ , N‚áõ*N‚Ä≤ ‚ü© ‚ü© =
        ‚ü® N‚Ä≤ , ‚ü® M‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤‚áõ*N‚Ä≤ , (M‚ÇÇ ‚áõ‚ü® M‚ÇÇ‚áõN ‚ü© N‚áõ*N‚Ä≤) ‚ü© ‚ü©

The step case may be illustrated as follows:

        L
       / \
      1   *
     /     \
    M‚ÇÅ (a)  M‚ÇÇ
   / \     /
  *   *   1
 /     \ /
M‚ÇÅ‚Ä≤(b)  N
 \     /
  *   *
   \ /
    N‚Ä≤

where downward lines are instances of ‚áõ or ‚áõ*, depending on how they are marked. Here (a) holds by strip and (b) holds by induction.

Proof of confluence for reduction

Confluence of reduction is a corollary of confluence for parallel reduction. From L ‚Äî‚Ü† M‚ÇÅ and L ‚Äî‚Ü† M‚ÇÇ we have L ‚áõ* M‚ÇÅ and L ‚áõ* M‚ÇÇ by betas-pars. Then by confluence we obtain some L such that M‚ÇÅ ‚áõ* N and M‚ÇÇ ‚áõ* N, from which we conclude that M‚ÇÅ ‚Äî‚Ü† N and M‚ÇÇ ‚Äî‚Ü† N by pars-betas.

confluence : ‚àÄ{Œì A} {L M‚ÇÅ M‚ÇÇ : Œì ‚ä¢ A}
  ‚Üí L ‚Äî‚Ü† M‚ÇÅ
  ‚Üí L ‚Äî‚Ü† M‚ÇÇ
    -----------------------------------
  ‚Üí Œ£[ N ‚àà Œì ‚ä¢ A ] (M‚ÇÅ ‚Äî‚Ü† N) √ó (M‚ÇÇ ‚Äî‚Ü† N)
confluence L‚Ü†M‚ÇÅ L‚Ü†M‚ÇÇ
    with par-confluence (betas-pars L‚Ü†M‚ÇÅ) (betas-pars L‚Ü†M‚ÇÇ)
... | ‚ü® N , ‚ü® M‚ÇÅ‚áõN , M‚ÇÇ‚áõN ‚ü© ‚ü© =
      ‚ü® N , ‚ü® pars-betas M‚ÇÅ‚áõN , pars-betas M‚ÇÇ‚áõN ‚ü© ‚ü©

Notes

Broadly speaking, this proof of confluence, based on parallel reduction, is due to W. Tait and P. Martin-Lof (see Barendredgt 1984, Section 3.2). Details of the mechanization come from several sources. The subst-par lemma is the ‚Äústrong substitutivity‚Äù lemma of Shafer, Tebbi, and Smolka (ITP 2015). The proofs of par-triangle, strip, and par-confluence are based on the notion of complete development by Takahashi (1995) and Pfenning‚Äôs 1992 technical report about the Church-Rosser theorem. In addition, we consulted Nipkow and Berghofer‚Äôs mechanization in Isabelle, which is based on an earlier article by Nipkow (JAR 1996).

Unicode

This chapter uses the following unicode:

‚áõ  U+21DB  RIGHTWARDS TRIPLE ARROW (\r== or \Rrightarrow)
‚Å∫  U+207A  SUPERSCRIPT PLUS SIGN   (\^+)
